commitResults.messageTitle: Add AI.md for iP.AI development tracking
Level-0: Rename Duke to MONDAY and implement greet/exit functionality
commitResults.messageBody:
The project is using the Duke template from the course repository.

The project needs to be renamed to MONDAY to match the chosen chatbot
name with a grumpy personality inspired by Wednesday Addams.

Let's,
* rename Duke.java to Monday.java
* implement greet functionality that displays a grumpy greeting
* implement exit functionality that accepts an "exit" command
* update build.gradle to reference the new Monday class
* update test scripts to run Monday instead of Duke
* update test expectations and input files
* update documentation to reflect MONDAY branding

The greet and exit functionality provides the foundation for future
increments. All Duke references have been removed from the codebase.

commitResults.messageTitle: Level-0: Fix greet/exit to match grumpy personality
commitResults.messageBody:
The AI's initial implementation had a polite tone that contradicts MONDAY's intended grumpy personality.

MONDAY should be cynical (like Wednesday Addams) to appeal to power users who prefer efficiency over pleasantries.

Let's correct the greeting and exit messages to match the specified grumpy personality and add horizontal separators.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add command echoing and use 'bye' for exit
commitResults.messageBody:
The application does not echo user commands and uses 'exit' to quit.

Echoing commands provides feedback that input was received. Using 'bye'
as the exit command is more user-friendly and follows the specification.

Let's change the exit command from 'exit' to 'bye' and add echoing for
all non-exit commands to display user input wrapped in dividers.

The else block in the command loop handles the echoing case.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update AI.md with Level-1 Echo development log
Move Monday class to monday package and add Javadoc
commitResults.messageBody:
Monday.java is in the default package without documentation.

Using a proper package structure improves code organization and
follows Java conventions. Adding Javadoc improves code readability.

Let's,
* move Monday.java to the monday package
* add class-level Javadoc describing the chatbot
* add method-level Javadoc for the main method
* update build.gradle mainClass to monday.Monday
* update test scripts to use the new package path

commitResults.messageTitle: Add task storage and listing functionality
commitResults.messageBody:
MONDAY currently only echoes user input.

Users need a way to store and view tasks to make the chatbot useful for
task management.

Let's add an in-memory task list that can:
- Store up to 100 tasks
- Display tasks with numbered list format
- Handle edge cases (empty input, empty list, max tasks)

The implementation uses ArrayList for flexibility and maintains the grumpy
personality in all user messages.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update AI.md with Level-2 development log
Add mark and unmark commands for task completion status
commitResults.messageBody:
Tasks are stored as strings without any completion status tracking.

Users need a way to mark tasks as done and not done to track their
progress.

Let's add a Task class with completion status and implement mark/unmark
commands to toggle task completion state.

The Task class provides a foundation for future task enhancements such
as deadlines and event types.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor mark/unmark commands and improve code quality
commitResults.messageBody:
Mark and unmark commands are case-sensitive while list and bye commands
are case-insensitive. There is also code duplication between handleMark
and handleUnmark methods, magic strings in Task class, and redundant
.toString() calls in Monday class.

These issues reduce code maintainability and create inconsistent user
experience across commands.

Let's,
* make mark and unmark commands case-insensitive to match other commands
* extract shared logic from handleMark/handleUnmark into a helper method
* replace substring-based parsing with split on whitespace approach
* extract magic strings "[X]" and "[ ]" as constants in Task class
* make Task.description field final as it is never reassigned
* remove redundant .toString() calls when printing tasks
* update documentation examples to include LINE separators
* document case-insensitivity for mark/unmark commands

These changes improve code quality by following DRY principle, eliminating
magic strings, and ensuring consistent command behavior across the codebase.

commitResults.messageTitle: docs: Add Level-3 development log and workflow observations
Add support for todo, deadline, and event task types
commitResults.messageBody:
Tasks currently only support basic descriptions without date/time information.

Users need to track different types of tasks: simple todos, deadlines with due dates, and events with time ranges.

Let's,
* add getTypeIcon() and getFullDescription() methods to Task class
* create ToDo, Deadline, and Event subclasses extending Task
* add handleToDo(), handleDeadline(), and handleEvent() command handlers
* update command detection to recognize todo/deadline/event commands
* update text UI tests to verify all three task types
* update user documentation with examples for each command

The inheritance-based design allows polymorphism, so existing mark/unmark/list commands work without modification. Each task type displays with a unique icon ([T], [D], [E]) and includes type-specific details in the description.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix exception handling to use specific types
Document Level-4 implementation in AI.md
Add dynamic greetings, help command, and exit alias
commitResults.messageBody:
Monday uses a static greeting message and only accepts "bye" to exit.
Users have no way to discover available commands without reading source
code. Some users may expect "exit" to work as a standard command.

These enhancements improve user experience while maintaining Monday's
grumpy personality throughout the application.

Let's,
* add getGrumpyGreeting() method that returns day-specific greetings
  using java.time.DayOfWeek
* add handleHelp() method to display all available commands with
  sarcastic descriptions
* accept both "bye" and "exit" commands to terminate the application
* update text UI tests to verify the new features work correctly

Using java.time.DayOfWeek provides accurate day detection without
external dependencies. The help command maintains Monday's personality
to stay consistent with the chatbot's character. Accepting "exit"
improves usability for users familiar with standard CLI conventions.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor greeting messages to use helper method
Response formatting: add blank lines around LINE separators
Text UI Testing: implement comprehensive automated tests
commitResults.messageBody:
Current testing only covers happy path scenarios.

Automated testing is needed to verify all command behaviors
and error conditions without manual testing.

Let's:
- Add 8 focused test files covering all commands and error paths
- Enhance test runners with pass/fail tracking and summary reports
- Test 13 unique error messages plus happy path scenarios
- Implement hybrid approach: multiple files for development,
  single combined file for grading submission

Test coverage includes:
- Empty input and empty list error handling
- Todo, deadline, and event command validation
- Mark/unmark validation (non-numeric, out of range)
- Case-insensitive command handling
- Edge cases (non-command input, exit alias)

commitResults.messageTitle: AI.md: document A-TextUiTesting increment
Error Handling: detect and reject all invalid user inputs
commitResults.messageBody:
Unknown commands and malformed inputs are currently being added as tasks.
Users receive no feedback when they enter invalid commands like "todo" (without
description) or unknown words like "blah".

Let's,
* Add helper methods to extract command words and validate known commands
* Refactor main command loop to use precise command detection
* Handle command-only inputs (e.g., "todo", "mark") with specific errors
* Show error messages for unknown commands instead of adding them as tasks
* Update test expectations to reflect new error handling behavior

This provides clear, immediate feedback for all invalid inputs while maintaining
MONDAY's grumpy personality throughout error messages.

commitResults.messageTitle: Code review: remove unused isKnownCommand() method
commitResults.messageBody:
The isKnownCommand() helper method was implemented but never used.
Command dispatch works through the if-else chain with a final else
block for unknown commands, making this method unnecessary.

This is a code quality cleanup based on reviewer feedback.

commitResults.messageTitle: AI.md: document Level-5 error handling increment
Add delete command to remove tasks from list
commitResults.messageBody:
Users cannot remove tasks from the list once added.

A delete command is needed for task management flexibility, allowing
users to remove completed or unwanted tasks.

Let's add a delete command that:
* adds handleTaskRemoval() helper method for task deletion logic
* adds handleDelete() wrapper method following mark/unmark pattern
* routes delete command in main() with proper error handling
* updates help text to include delete command
* adds comprehensive test cases for all delete scenarios

The implementation follows the existing mark/unmark command pattern
for consistency and reuses validation methods for error handling.

commitResults.messageTitle: AI.md: document Level-6 delete command increment
A-Enums: Use Java enums to replace hardcoded strings
commitResults.messageBody:
The codebase uses hardcoded strings for task icons, parameter prefixes,
and command words. These scattered string literals are error-prone and
make the code harder to maintain.

Using enums provides type safety, prevents typos, and centralizes all
constants in one place. Adding new commands or task types becomes
simpler and safer.

Let's introduce three Java enums:
* TaskType enum - centralizes task type icons ([T], [D], [E], [])
* TaskPrefix enum - centralizes parameter prefixes (/by, /from, /to)
* CommandType enum - centralizes command words with alias support

Enums demonstrate proper Java features including state (icon strings),
methods (getIcon(), getPrefix(), getCommand()), factory methods
(fromString()), and switch statement compatibility. The CommandType
enum also supports command aliases (e.g., "exit" â†’ "bye").

This improves code quality by providing compiler checks and IDE
auto-completion while maintaining all existing functionality.

commitResults.messageTitle: AI.md: document A-Enums increment
Greeting: add current date display and update help text formatting
commitResults.messageBody:
The greeting message does not show the current date, making the
day-specific message less contextual. Additionally, the help text
formatting could be improved for better readability.

Let's add a date display line before the day-specific message and update
the help text to use parenthetical formatting.

The date display helps users understand what day it is when seeing the
day-specific message, and the parenthetical format makes the help text
feel more conversational.

commitResults.messageTitle: Greeting: ensure English locale for date formatting
Docs: update expected output to match actual greeting behavior
commitResults.messageBody:
README.md and test expected files show an outdated greeting format that
does not match the actual program behavior.

The actual greeting includes a dynamic date, day-specific messages, and
a grumpy personality that varies by day of the week. Documentation and
tests should reflect the actual program behavior for accuracy.

Let's update the documentation and test expected files to show the
actual grumpy greeting format with date line and correct help text.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add file persistence for tasks
commitResults.messageBody:
Tasks are currently stored in memory only and are lost when the
application exits.

Users expect their tasks to persist between sessions so they can
continue where they left off.

Let's add a Storage class to save/load tasks from disk in pipe-delimited
format, and integrate it to auto-save on every task modification.

commitResults.messageTitle: Remove line content from corrupted line error message
Merge branch-Level-7: File persistence
AI.md: Add Level-7 file persistence entry
Add enhanced corrupted data handling for file persistence
commitResults.messageBody:
Corrupted lines in the data file are silently skipped without
notifying the user or providing any recovery option.

Users should be informed when data corruption is detected and have
a way to recover their corrupted data.

Let's add a LoadResult wrapper class to track corruption statistics,
enhance field validation to reject empty critical fields, display
a corruption summary on startup, and automatically backup
corrupted lines to monday.txt.corrupted for possible recovery.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor: apply code review fixes
commitResults.messageBody: Fix hollow state and use List interface

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor: use List interface and extract constants
Save on exit to clean corrupted lines
Merge branch 'branch-Level-7-stretch'
Update AI.md for Level-7 stretch goal
Level-8: Add date/time support and view command
commitResults.messageBody:
Tasks currently store dates as strings without proper date parsing.

The view command requires date comparison to filter tasks by scheduled
date. Using java.time classes enables proper date manipulation and
comparison.

Let's,
* add VIEW enum to CommandType
* change Deadline to use LocalDateTime instead of String
* change Event to use LocalDateTime for from/to fields
* add parseDateTime() factory methods with multi-format support
* update Storage to serialize/deserialize LocalDateTime
* add handleView() method to filter tasks by date
* add parseViewDate() helper for view command date parsing

Using LocalDateTime allows date comparison operations and provides
better type safety than String-based dates.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor: extract shared DateTimeParser utility
commitResults.messageBody:
Deadline and Event classes contain duplicate formatter constants and parsing logic.

Code duplication makes maintenance harder and violates the DRY principle.

Let's,
* extract common formatters and parseDateTime() to DateTimeParser utility class
* update Deadline and Event to use shared formatters
* update Storage to use DateTimeParser.STORAGE_FORMATTER
* update Monday to extract inline formatters to constants
* fix Storage to catch DateTimeParseException instead of generic Exception

Centralizing date parsing logic ensures consistent formatting across the
application and reduces code duplication.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor: remove redundant wrapper methods
Fix error message to use correct datetime format
Merge branch 'branch-Level-8'
Docs: update AI.md with Level-8 entry
Extract Ui class from Monday
commitResults.messageBody:
Monday.java currently handles all user interface operations through
static methods mixed with application logic. This violates the Single
Responsibility Principle and makes the code harder to test and maintain.

Let's extract all UI-related functionality into a dedicated Ui class to
separate display concerns from business logic.

The Ui class now handles:
- Display methods (showResponse, showGreeting, showTaskList, etc.)
- Input reading (readCommand)
- All grumpy personality messages
- Scanner lifecycle management

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor Storage to instance-based class
commitResults.messageBody:
Storage currently uses static methods for all operations. This makes
testing difficult and doesn't follow object-oriented design principles.

Let's convert Storage to use instance methods with a constructor that
accepts data directory and file name parameters.

commitResults.messageTitle: Extract TaskList class from Monday
commitResults.messageBody:
Monday.java currently manages task operations directly using List<Task>.
This mixes task management logic with the main application logic.

Let's extract all task management operations into a dedicated TaskList
class that encapsulates the task collection and provides methods for
common operations.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add ParseException and CommandException classes
commitResults.messageBody:
These exception classes will be used for the Command pattern
implementation. ParseException will be thrown during command
parsing, while CommandException will be thrown during command
execution.

commitResults.messageTitle: Create Command pattern foundation and simple commands
commitResults.messageBody:
Let's set up the Command pattern infrastructure with abstract Command
base class and CommandResult for tracking command execution results.

Simple commands implemented:
- ExitCommand: Displays farewell and exits
- ListCommand: Lists all tasks
- HelpCommand: Displays help information

commitResults.messageTitle: Add task manipulation commands
commitResults.messageBody:
Let's add commands for task manipulation:
- MarkCommand: Marks/unmarks tasks (single command with boolean flag)
- DeleteCommand: Deletes tasks from the list
- AddCommand: Abstract base for add commands
- AddToDoCommand: Adds simple todo tasks

commitResults.messageTitle: Add AddDeadlineCommand and AddEventCommand
commitResults.messageBody:
Let's add the remaining add commands for tasks with date/time:
- AddDeadlineCommand: Adds tasks with due dates
- AddEventCommand: Adds tasks with start/end times

commitResults.messageTitle: Extract Parser class and add ViewCommand
commitResults.messageBody:
Let's extract all command parsing logic into a dedicated Parser class
that creates Command objects. The Parser now handles:

- Extracting command word and arguments
- Validating input format
- Creating appropriate Command objects
- Parsing dates and task numbers

ViewCommand added to filter tasks by date.

commitResults.messageTitle: Replace switch statement with Command pattern execution
commitResults.messageBody:
Let's refactor the main loop to use the Command pattern. The switch
statement and all handler methods have been replaced with:

- Parser creates Command objects from user input
- Command.execute() handles the operation
- CommandResult signals when to save/exit
- Main loop is now just ~40 lines vs 470 lines

All handler methods, parser helpers, and validation code removed from
Monday.java - they're now in their respective Command classes.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor: extract duplicate error message method to TaskList
commitResults.messageBody:
The getInvalidTaskErrorMessage method was duplicated in both MarkCommand
and DeleteCommand. Let's extract this to TaskList where it logically
belongs, as it operates on TaskList state.

commitResults.messageTitle: Style: reorder constant before instance fields in Storage
commitResults.messageBody:
Per SE-EDU coding standards, constants should be declared before
instance fields. Moved CORRUPTED_LINE_MESSAGE constant to proper position.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-A-MoreOOP'
Docs: update AI.md with A-MoreOOP entry
commitResults.messageBody:
AI pushed beyond optional requirements with production-quality
Command pattern plan. Prompt engineering matters - engaged another
agent to craft the prompt. Frequent commits as instructed improved
workflow vs previous increments.

commitResults.messageTitle: A-Packages: Organize classes into logical subpackages
commitResults.messageBody:
All classes are currently in a flat monday package structure.

Organizing classes into logical subpackages improves code organization,
separates concerns, and makes the codebase easier to navigate and
maintain.

Let's organize classes into 7 subpackages based on their responsibilities:
* monday.task/ - Task model classes (Task, ToDo, Deadline, Event, TaskList)
* monday.command/ - Command pattern classes (14 files)
* monday.parser/ - Parser class
* monday.storage/ - Storage class
* monday.ui/ - Ui class
* monday.exception/ - Custom exception classes
* monday.util/ - Shared utilities (DateTimeParser)

This separation follows Single Responsibility Principle and improves
namespace management.

commitResults.messageTitle: Remove unused TaskPrefix import from CommandType
Merge branch 'branch-A-Packages'
Docs: update AI.md with A-Packages entry
Docs: update AI.md with A-Gradle entry
commitResults.messageBody: A-Gradle increment completed with Gradle enhancements.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add JUnit tests for A-JUnit increment
commitResults.messageBody:
The project has no JUnit tests to verify code correctness. JUnit tests
ensure code correctness, catch bugs early, and make refactoring safer.

Let's add 10 test classes covering non-trivial methods from multiple
classes:
* TaskTest, ToDoTest, DeadlineTest, EventTest - Task hierarchy tests
* TaskListTest, LoadResultTest - Collection and wrapper tests
* ParserTest - Command parsing with comprehensive error cases
* StorageTest - File I/O with corruption handling
* DateTimeParserTest - Date/time parsing with multiple formats
* CommandTypeTest - Command matching with aliases

All tests follow SE-EDU Java coding standards and use descriptive
naming conventions.

commitResults.messageTitle: TaskListTest: verify defensive copying with assertNotSame
Merge branch-A-JUnit: Add JUnit tests for A-JUnit increment
Docs: update AI.md with A-JUnit entry
A-CodingStandard: Fix import ordering for SE-EDU compliance
commitResults.messageBody:
Import ordering does not match the project's Checkstyle configuration.

The Checkstyle configuration requires project imports (monday.*)
before standard library imports (java.*) to maintain consistent
import organization across the codebase.

Let's reorder imports in 17 files to match the Checkstyle requirements.

This ensures consistent code style and prevents Checkstyle violations
during build.

commitResults.messageTitle: Level-9: Add find command to search tasks by keyword
commitResults.messageBody:
Users need a way to locate specific tasks by searching for keywords
in the task description.

A case-insensitive substring search is more user-friendly because
users cannot be expected to remember the exact case or full text
of their task descriptions.

Let's add a FindCommand class and integrate it into the command
processing flow.

The search performs case-insensitive matching on task descriptions
and displays all matching tasks in a numbered list.

commitResults.messageTitle: A-JavaDoc: Document AI review finding - JavaDoc already complete
commitResults.messageBody:
AI review verified all 28 Java source files have complete JavaDoc
coverage from previous development work.

No code changes were needed as the increment requirement was already
satisfied by professional AI work on earlier increments.

commitResults.messageTitle: Level-9: Add find command to search tasks by keyword
commitResults.messageBody:
Users need a way to locate specific tasks by searching for keywords
in the task description.

A case-insensitive substring search is more user-friendly because
users cannot be expected to remember the exact case or full text
of their task descriptions.

Let's add a FindCommand class and integrate it into the command
processing flow.

The search performs case-insensitive matching on task descriptions
and displays all matching tasks in a numbered list.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master' into branch-Level-9
A-Cheer: Add cheer command with colored grumpy quotes
commitResults.messageBody:
A cheer command has been added to display random grumpy motivational quotes.

The cheer command reads quotes from data/cheer.txt and displays one at random
with yellow ANSI coloring (\u001B[33m) for the quote text.

Let's add the CHEER enum value to CommandType, create CheerCommand class,
add showCheerMessage method to Ui, and update Parser to handle the cheer command.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'master' into branch-A-Cheer
Docs: update AI.md with multi-branch session observations
commitResults.messageBody:
Documented the multi-branch implementation session for A-CodingStandard,
Level-9, and A-Cheer increments.

Key lesson learned: parallel branch development is very troublesome
and should be avoided when not necessary. External AI reviews (Codex,
GitHub Copilot) provided valuable feedback for code quality.

commitResults.messageTitle: A-CheckStyle: enable suppressions and fix import order
commitResults.messageBody:
CheckStyle runs but does not apply the suppressions file.
Main and test code also have import order violations.

SE-EDU convention requires project imports (monday.*) before java.*.

Let's wire up SuppressionFilter in checkstyle.xml and reorder imports to
match the convention.

commitResults.messageTitle: Parser: fix find command not being parsed
commitResults.messageBody:
The find command is implemented but Parser does not route FIND tokens to
parseFindCommand().

This makes "find" behave as an unknown command.

Let's add the missing FIND case in the parser switch statement.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add cheer command to parser
Docs: update AI.md with A-CheckStyle observations
Level-10: Add JavaFX GUI
commitResults.messageBody:
Monday is currently a CLI-only application.

A GUI will make the application more accessible and provide
visual feedback for user interactions.

Let's,
* add JavaFX dependencies to build.gradle with platform-specific
  artifacts
* create Launcher.java as the main entry point
* create MainWindow.java for the JavaFX application window
* create DialogBox.java for user/bot dialog bubbles
* modify Monday.java to extend javafx.application.Application
* add getResponse() method to Monday for GUI command handling
* modify Ui.java to track and return responses for GUI display
* modify Storage.java to expose load results to GUI

The GUI uses a dialog-based interface similar to modern chat apps,
preserving MONDAY's grumpy personality while providing visual
feedback.

commitResults.messageTitle: Level-10: Merge JavaFX GUI feature branch
commitResults.messageBody:
Level-10 GUI feature is complete and tested on branch-Level-10.

The branch adds JavaFX GUI with full backward compatibility for CLI
mode. All tests pass and code review verified SE-EDU standards
compliance.

Let's merge branch-Level-10 into master using --no-ff to preserve
feature branch history.

commitResults.messageTitle: Docs: update AI.md with Level-10 observations
A-Varargs: use varargs for command aliases
commitResults.messageBody:
CommandType enum uses array syntax for aliases which requires
explicit array creation.

Varargs provides cleaner syntax while maintaining the same
functionality.

Let's change the constructor parameter from String[] to String...

commitResults.messageTitle: Docs: update AI.md with A-Varargs observations
Docs: add Gradle run instructions for Windows
A-UnitTesting: add unit tests for command layer
commitResults.messageBody:
CommandResult and MarkCommand classes lack test coverage.

The CommandResult class is used by all commands to signal save/exit
behavior but has no tests. MarkCommand handles mark/unmark operations
but also has no dedicated test class.

Let's add CommandResultTest with 5 tests covering all boolean flag
combinations, and MarkCommandTest with 5 tests using Mockito for
happy path and error handling scenarios.

commitResults.messageTitle: MarkCommandTest: fix import order violations
commitResults.messageBody:
Imports violate Checkstyle rules for order and static import sorting.

Let's reorder imports to place monday.* before org.* and sort
static imports alphabetically.

commitResults.messageTitle: MarkCommandTest: improve assertions and fix negative value
commitResults.messageBody:
Tests only verified exception type, not the error message content.
Negative test used 0 (non-negative) instead of truly negative value.

Let's add assertEquals assertions to verify exception messages match
TaskList error messages, and change test value from 0 to -1 to match
the "negative" test name intent.

commitResults.messageTitle: A-UnitTesting: add unit tests for command layer
commitResults.messageBody:
CommandResult and MarkCommand classes lack test coverage.

The CommandResult class is used by all commands to signal save/exit
behavior but has no tests. MarkCommand handles mark/unmark operations
but also has no dedicated test class.

Let's add CommandResultTest with 5 tests covering all boolean flag
combinations, and MarkCommandTest with 5 tests using Mockito for
happy path and error handling scenarios.

commitResults.messageTitle: Docs: update AI.md with A-UnitTesting
Apply dark theme to GUI
commitResults.messageBody:
The GUI currently uses light theme with white backgrounds which can

cause eye strain during extended use.

A dark theme provides better visual comfort for users working in low-

light environments or for extended periods.

Let's,

* apply dark gray color scheme (#1e1e1e, #2d2d2d, #3d3d3d, #3d4a5c)

* fix resizing by changing input field and send button to bottom anchors

* style scrollbars with dark theme colors

Using bottom anchors instead of top anchors ensures proper resizing

behavior as the dialog content grows.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add assertions to document invariants
commitResults.messageBody:
The codebase lacks explicit documentation of important assumptions
and invariants that must hold true during execution.

Without explicit documentation, these critical assumptions are only
implied in the code, making it harder for developers to understand
the expected behavior and catch bugs early.

Let's add assert statements across task, command, parser, storage,
and UI classes to document preconditions, postconditions, and
invariants.

Using assertions provides runtime checks during development and
serves as executable documentation that clearly communicates the
intended behavior of the code.

commitResults.messageTitle: Remove redundant null checks
commitResults.messageBody:
The code contains redundant null checks that verify conditions already
guaranteed by Java's type system. These assertions are unnecessary and
add noise to the code.

Removing these checks improves code clarity and reduces unnecessary
defensive programming.

Let's remove redundant null checks from TaskList and Ui classes.

This makes the code more maintainable by eliminating checks that can
never fail due to Java's type guarantees.

commitResults.messageTitle: Remove assertions causing test failures
Extract parser, storage, and ui classes
commitResults.messageBody:
Parser, Storage, and Ui classes have grown large and handle multiple
responsibilities.

Large classes with multiple responsibilities are harder to understand,
test, and maintain. They violate the Single Responsibility Principle.

Let's,
* extract CommandParser, DateParser, TaskArgumentParser, and
  TaskNumberParser from Parser
* extract FileStorage, TaskSerializer, TaskDeserializer, and
  CorruptionHandler from Storage
* extract MessageFormatter, TaskListFormatter, GreetingGenerator, and
  ResponseBuilder from Ui

Extracting focused, single-responsibility classes improves code
organization, makes testing easier, and follows the Single Responsibility
Principle. Each new class has a clear, well-defined purpose.

commitResults.messageTitle: [Assertions] Add assertions to document invariants
commitResults.messageBody:
The codebase lacks explicit documentation of important assumptions and invariants. This makes it difficult for developers to understand the expected state of the program and may lead to bugs when these assumptions are violated.

Let's add Java assertions to document important invariants throughout the codebase.

Assertions provide a clear way to document assumptions and can catch violations during development. They are disabled in production by default, so they do not affect performance in production builds.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor: Extract constants and improve separation
commitResults.messageBody:
The Monday class and MainWindow contain mixed concerns with constants, UI logic, and command processing
This makes the code difficult to maintain and understand, with tight coupling between components
Let's extract constants into dedicated files and create separate classes for application initialization, command processing, and GUI orchestration
This improves code organization and follows single responsibility principle for better maintainability

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge master into branch-A-CodeQuality
Merge branch-A-CodeQuality into master
commitResults.messageBody: The branch-A-CodeQuality branch has 14 refactoring tasks completed, all verified and committed, with all 181 tests passing. Master needs to integrate these code quality improvements to improve the overall codebase maintainability and adherence to best practices. Let's merge branch-A-CodeQuality into master using a non-fast-forward merge to preserve the branch history and make it clear when the code quality improvements were integrated.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor to use Java Streams API
commitResults.messageBody:
Several methods across TaskList, Storage, Ui, and CommandType classes use
traditional for-loops and manual iteration to process collections.

Traditional loops are verbose and can be harder to read. Java Streams API
provides a more declarative and functional approach to collection
processing that improves code maintainability.

Let's replace traditional loops with Stream operations in 8 methods across
4 files, reducing code by ~26 lines while maintaining all functionality.

Streams provide a more concise and expressive way to process collections.
The functional style separates the "what" from the "how", making code
easier to understand and maintain.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge master into branch-A-Streams
Merge branch-A-Streams into master
commitResults.messageBody:
The master branch currently uses traditional iteration patterns for
collection operations across TaskList, Storage, Ui, and CommandType
classes. These implementations rely on explicit loops and manual
iteration which can be verbose and harder to maintain.

There is a need to modernize the codebase by adopting Java Streams API.
The Streams API provides a more declarative and functional approach to
collection processing, improving code readability and maintainability.

This merge integrates the branch-A-Streams feature branch which refactors
eight methods across four files to use Java Streams API. The refactoring
replaces traditional for-loops with stream operations for filtering,
mapping, and collecting operations.

Using Streams API improves code expressiveness and reduces boilerplate.
The functional style makes the code more concise and easier to understand.
All 123 unit tests pass, confirming that the refactoring maintains
correctness while improving code quality.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add remind command
commitResults.messageBody:
Users have no way to view upcoming tasks and deadlines at a glance.
They must manually scan through the entire task list to identify
which tasks require immediate attention.

A reminder feature would help users prioritize their work by
displaying tasks sorted by urgency. This reduces the cognitive load
of identifying important tasks and improves task management
efficiency.

Let's,
* add a RemindCommand class that displays tasks sorted by urgency
  level
* implement TaskCounts and UrgencyLevel helper classes for task
  classification
* add getTaskCounts() and getEarliestUpcomingTask() methods to
  TaskList
* update the UI to support displaying reminder summaries

Urgency-based sorting provides a clear visual hierarchy that helps
users quickly identify high-priority tasks.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix GUI response handling
commitResults.messageBody:
The GUI does not display responses when users execute commands such as
help, list, or add. This occurs because the response formatters only
print to System.out for CLI and do not update the GUI's response
storage.

Users cannot receive feedback or confirmation when using the GUI,
making it completely non-functional. This breaks the core user
experience and prevents any meaningful interaction with the application
through the graphical interface.

Let's,
* add build methods to ResponseBuilder and TaskListFormatter that
  return formatted strings without printing
* update Ui methods to call build methods and pass results to
  showResponse
* ensure lastResponse is always set for both CLI and GUI operations

Separating string building from printing allows the same response
generation logic to serve both CLI and GUI interfaces. This
architectural change maintains consistency across both interfaces
while ensuring the GUI can retrieve responses for display.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update AI.md for week6
A-JavaDoc: Document AI review finding - JavaDoc already complete
commitResults.messageBody:
A-JavaDoc: Document AI review finding - JavaDoc already complete

AI review verified all 28 Java source files have complete JavaDoc
coverage from previous development work.

No code changes were needed as the increment requirement was already
satisfied by professional AI work on earlier increments.

commitResults.messageTitle: A-CodingStandard: Fix import ordering for SE-EDU compliance
commitResults.messageBody:
A-CodingStandard: Fix import ordering for SE-EDU compliance

Import ordering does not match the project's Checkstyle configuration.

The Checkstyle configuration requires project imports (monday.*)
before standard library imports (java.*) to maintain consistent
import organization across the codebase.

Let's reorder imports in 17 files to match the Checkstyle requirements.

This ensures consistent code style and prevents Checkstyle violations
during build.

commitResults.messageTitle: Level-9: Add find command to search tasks by keyword
commitResults.messageBody:
Level-9: Add find command to search tasks by keyword

Users need a way to locate specific tasks by searching for keywords
in the task description.

A case-insensitive substring search is more user-friendly because
users cannot be expected to remember the exact case or full text
of their task descriptions.

Let's add a FindCommand class and integrate it into the command
processing flow.

The search performs case-insensitive matching on task descriptions
and displays all matching tasks in a numbered list.

commitResults.messageTitle: A-Cheer: Add cheer command with colored grumpy quotes
commitResults.messageBody:
A-Cheer: Add cheer command with colored grumpy quotes

Users sometimes need motivation when coding.

A cheer command that displays grumpy, sarcastic quotes fits Monday's
personality better than traditional motivational messages.

Let's add a CheerCommand that reads quotes from a text file and
displays them in yellow ANSI color for visual emphasis.

The quotes are stored in data/cheer.txt and can be easily customized.

commitResults.messageTitle: A-CheckStyle: add CheckStyle plugin with SE-EDU rules
commitResults.messageBody:
The project has no automated code style checking.

Automated style checking ensures consistent code quality and
catches violations before they become technical debt.

Let's,
* add CheckStyle plugin with SE-EDU standard configuration
* configure suppressions for JUnit test naming conventions
* fix pre-existing parser bugs (find and cheer commands)
* fix import order violations across codebase
